questions.text:
A 78-year-old man comes to the physician for a medical evaluation 5 days before undergoing abdominal hernia repair. Two years ago, he underwent a mechanical mitral valve replacement for chronic primary mitral regurgitation. He has hypertension. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. Current medications include warfarin, hydrochlorothiazide, and aspirin. His temperature is 37.1°C (99.3°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 126/74 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination reveals a mitral click. The abdomen is soft and nontender. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
13.1 g/dL


Leukocyte count
8900/mm3



Platelet count
230,000/mm3



Prothrombin time
23 seconds (INR = 2.1)


Creatinine clearance
102 mL/min


Results of urinalysis are within the reference ranges. An x-ray of the chest shows no abnormalities. An ECG shows signs of mild left atrial enlargement. Which of the following instructions regarding medication is the most appropriate at this time?

choices.text: Stop warfarin now, start dalteparin therapy in 2 days, and discontinue 24 hours prior to surgery
Switch warfarin to dabigatran and discontinue 48-72 hours prior to surgery
Stop warfarin and start unfractionated heparin now, discontinue 4-6 hours prior to surgery
Warfarin intake can be continued
Stop warfarin now and continue post-surgery

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Preoperative bridging anticoagulation involves the temporary administration of a short-acting parenteral anticoagulant after VKA interruption. Because warfarin has a half-life of approximately 36–42 hours, starting the low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) dalteparin 2 days after discontinuation (or after 2–3 missed doses) allows warfarin to reach subtherapeutic levels. This timing ensures that the patient is not at a higher than necessary risk of hemorrhage from two anticoagulants. Alternatively, INR can be monitored and bridging anticoagulation started as soon as INR is in the subtherapeutic range. Because LMWHs have a short half-life (e.g., 3–5 hours for dalteparin), discontinuing LMWH 24 hours before surgery minimizes the risk of excessive bleeding during and immediately after the procedure. After surgery, VKAs can usually be resumed after 12–24 hours.

Preoperative bridging anticoagulation is recommended for patients at high risk of developing perioperative thromboemboli. Risk factors include history of stroke or transient ischemic attack (TIA) in the past 3 months, presence of a mechanical mitral heart valve with major risk factors for stroke (e.g., hypertension, age ≥ 75 years), atrial fibrillation with a CHA2DS2-VASc score ≥ 7, history of venous thromboembolism (VTE) in the past 3 months, rheumatic valvular heart disease, and active cancer with increased VTE risk (e.g., gastric or pancreatic cancer). In most patients, preoperative bridging anticoagulation is not recommended due to the risk of perioperative bleeding.

B) INCORRECT:

Starting the direct thrombin inhibitor dabigatran immediately after discontinuing warfarin would not allow adequate time for warfarin to be eliminated from the body, since the half-life of warfarin is approximately 36–42 hours. The patient would be at a high risk of bleeding with two anticoagulants at the same time. Moreover, dabigatran is contraindicated in patients with a mechanical valve because it has been shown to increase the risk of thromboembolic events in this patient population. Finally, dabigatran has a half-life of 15 hours, making it less optimal than drugs with shorter half-lives because it is not reliably eliminated from the body immediately before surgery.

C) INCORRECT:

Unfractionated heparin (UFH) can be used as bridging anticoagulation and should be discontinued 4–6 hours before surgery to minimize the risk of perioperative bleeding. However, starting UFH immediately after discontinuing warfarin does not allow adequate time for warfarin to be eliminated from the body, because its half-life is approximately 36–42 hours. The patient would be at a high risk of bleeding with two anticoagulants at the same time. UFH is usually started 2 days after discontinuing warfarin, allowing adequate time for warfarin to reach subtherapeutic levels.

D) INCORRECT:

Generally, warfarin may be continued for procedures with a low risk of perioperative bleeding (e.g., cataract surgery, pacemaker placement, dermatological surgery). This patient will undergo surgery that poses a moderate bleeding risk, and continuing warfarin during the perioperative period poses an unacceptably high risk of bleeding.

E) INCORRECT:

Stopping warfarin decreases the risk of perioperative bleeding. However, this patient has a high thromboembolic risk, and stopping warfarin without bridging therapy with another anticoagulant increases the risk of DVT and/or pulmonary embolism.
questions.hint: This patient will undergo surgery with a moderate risk of perioperative bleeding in 5 days, and his mechanical mitral heart valve, age, and hypertension increase his risk of thromboembolism. To balance these risks, the Vitamin K antagonist warfarin should be discontinued (VKA interruption), and preoperative bridging anticoagulation should be initiated.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old woman with recently diagnosed uterine cancer presents for preoperative evaluation before abdominal hysterectomy. Ten years ago, she had mechanical heart valve replacement for mitral stenosis that was rheumatic in origin. She has chronic kidney disease but no history of atrial fibrillation or stroke. She takes warfarin 5 mg daily.
The patient currently has a mechanical first heart sound, a soft diastolic murmur, and normal left ventricular function. Laboratory testing reveals an elevated but stable creatinine level of 3.5 mg/dL (reference range, 0.6–1.1), an estimated glomerular filtration rate of 15 mL/min/1.73 m2 (reference range, ≥ 60 mL/min/1.73 m2), and an international normalized ratio of 2.7.
Which one of the following perioperative anticoagulation bridging strategies is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Discontinue warfarin 5 days before surgery; initiate a therapeutic dose of intravenous unfractionated heparin when the international normalized ratio falls below 2.5
Discontinue warfarin 3 days before surgery; initiate a prophylactic dose of subcutaneous low-molecular-weight heparin when the international normalized ratio falls below 2.0
Discontinue warfarin 5 days before surgery; initiate a therapeutic dose of subcutaneous low-molecular-weight heparin when the international normalized ratio falls below 2.5
Discontinue warfarin 3 days before surgery; initiate twice-daily intramuscular doses of unfractionated heparin
Continue warfarin with an international normalized ratio target of 1.5 to 2.0

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Patients with mechanical mitral valves are at high risk for valve thrombosis, stroke, and arterial thromboembolism and are treated with warfarin to a goal international normalized ratio (INR) of 3.0 (range, 2.5–3.5). They require anticoagulation bridging with low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH) or unfractionated heparin (UFH), both before and after surgery, while warfarin is withheld and the INR is subtherapeutic.

Guideline recommendations vary to some extent about whether UFH and LMWH are equally acceptable for bridging in patients with mechanical valves. LMWH is easier to administer and is now preferred by many clinicians for patients with normal or mildly reduced renal function. However, in a patient with severely impaired renal function, intravenous UFH is preferable because LMWH is primarily renally excreted; use of LMWH in such patients is associated with increased risk for bleeding complications.

Patients who have had an isolated mechanical aortic valve replacement with no concomitant risk factors for embolic events, such as atrial fibrillation or prior stroke, are at low risk and do not require bridging. The risk for bleeding rises with perioperative bridging, and the decision about when to restart heparin and warfarin after surgery must be individualized. That decision should account for a patient’s risk for stroke or thromboembolism, his or her risk for bleeding, and the adequacy of postoperative hemostasis.

Key learning point: In a patient with a mechanical mitral valve, the most appropriate perioperative anticoagulation bridging strategy to prevent stroke and arterial thromboembolism is to discontinue warfarin 5 days before surgery and initiate a therapeutic dose of intravenous unfractionated heparin when the international normalized ratio falls below 2.5.

B) INCORRECT:

Prophylactic doses of LMWH are insufficient to reduce the risk for major thrombosis in a patient with a mechanical mitral valve. Allowing the international normalized ratio to fall below 2.0 increases the risk for thrombosis and is not recommended without heparin as a bridging therapy.

C) INCORRECT:

Guideline recommendations vary to some extent about whether UFH and LMWH are equally acceptable for bridging in patients with mechanical valves. LMWH is easier to administer and is now preferred by many clinicians for patients with normal or mildly reduced renal function. However, in a patient with severely impaired renal function, intravenous UFH is preferable because LMWH is primarily renally excreted; use of LMWH in such patients is associated with increased risk for bleeding complications.

D) INCORRECT:

Prophylactic doses of intramuscular UFH are insufficient to reduce the risk for major thrombosis in a patient with a mechanical mitral valve.

E) INCORRECT:

Continuing warfarin would confer unacceptable bleeding risk in a patient undergoing major abdominal surgery. Allowing the international normalized ratio to fall below 2.0 increases the risk for thrombosis and is not recommended without heparin as a bridging therapy.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man presents with 2 days of dental pain from a tooth infection for which his dentist has recommended a dental extraction. He had a spontaneous deep-vein thrombosis diagnosed in his left common femoral vein 2 months ago and has been taking warfarin since then. He has been unable to afford a direct oral anticoagulant because he does not have health insurance. His international normalized ratio has been at target for the past 6 weeks, and the most recent value was 2.4.
Which one of the following anticoagulant management approaches is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Discontinue the warfarin for at least 48 hours before the procedure, and provide samples of dabigatran to be taken daily until the warfarin is restarted
Discontinue the warfarin for at least 48 hours before the procedure, and start daily enoxaparin to continue until the warfarin is restarted
Discontinue the warfarin, wait 24 hours, and then proceed with the extraction
Discontinue the warfarin, wait until the international normalized ratio is less than 1.5, and then proceed with the extraction
Continue warfarin and proceed with the extraction

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

There is no need to replace warfarin with enoxaparin or dabigatran if a patient is appropriately anticoagulated on warfarin. If this patient had been able to take a direct oral anticoagulant (DOAC) to treat his deep-vein thrombosis, then there would be less data to guide the appropriate periprocedural anticoagulation management. Most of the available data indicate that continuing DOACs for dental procedures is as safe as continuing warfarin; thus, DOACs are usually continued in patients undergoing minor dental procedures. However, some experts recommend stopping the DOAC for 12 to 24 hours before the procedure to reduce bleeding risk. Because of the rapid cessation and onset of their anticoagulant effect, DOACs can be stopped for a much shorter period of time than warfarin can, leading to a much shorter window of thrombotic risk.

B) INCORRECT:

There is no need to replace warfarin with enoxaparin or dabigatran if a patient is appropriately anticoagulated on warfarin. If this patient had been able to take a direct oral anticoagulant (DOAC) to treat his deep-vein thrombosis, then there would be less data to guide the appropriate periprocedural anticoagulation management. Most of the available data indicate that continuing DOACs for dental procedures is as safe as continuing warfarin; thus, DOACs are usually continued in patients undergoing minor dental procedures. However, some experts recommend stopping the DOAC for 12 to 24 hours before the procedure to reduce bleeding risk. Because of the rapid cessation and onset of their anticoagulant effect, DOACs can be stopped for a much shorter period of time than warfarin can, leading to a much shorter window of thrombotic risk.

C) INCORRECT:

For minor dental, ophthalmologic, and dermatologic procedures that have a low risk of bleeding or a risk of bleeding that can be controlled with local hemostatic methods (such as cautery for skin procedures or oral antifibrinolytic mouthwashes for dental procedures), warfarin can be continued without interruption.

D) INCORRECT:

For minor dental, ophthalmologic, and dermatologic procedures that have a low risk of bleeding or a risk of bleeding that can be controlled with local hemostatic methods (such as cautery for skin procedures or oral antifibrinolytic mouthwashes for dental procedures), warfarin can be continued without interruption.

E) CORRECT:

For minor dental, ophthalmologic, and dermatologic procedures that have a low risk of bleeding or a risk of bleeding that can be controlled with local hemostatic methods (such as cautery for skin procedures or oral antifibrinolytic mouthwashes for dental procedures), warfarin can be continued without interruption. Examples of a minor procedure include tooth extraction, excision of basal- or squamous-cell carcinoma, and cataract surgery.

Warfarin should not be discontinued in patients who are at risk for recurrent thrombosis, such as a patient with a spontaneous deep-vein thrombosis, unless the patient is bleeding or has a major urgent procedure planned.

Key learning point: The best strategy to manage warfarin in a patient who needs a minor procedure is to continue the anticoagulant therapy.

questions.text: What is the most appropriate strategy for assessing the bleeding risk in a 25-year-old patient who is scheduled for elective inguinal hernia repair and reports an occasional history of easy bruising on the extremities?

choices.text: Perform a platelet-function screen
Obtain a thorough personal and family medical history and bleeding history
Measure bleeding time
Measure activated partial-thromboplastin time
Measure prothrombin time

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A platelet-function assay measures both platelet adhesion and aggregation. It is often used to screen for von Willebrand disease or other inherited platelet function defects. A patient’s report of “easy bruising” without a history of more substantial or serious bleeding is not generally an indication for additional evaluation.

B) CORRECT:

In assessing bleeding risk, a careful medical and surgical history is of primary importance. In the absence of a personal or family bleeding history (including features that might suggest diagnoses such as Marfan syndrome, Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, or Cushing syndrome), preoperative coagulation testing is not indicated for surgeries with low bleeding risk. If the personal history or physical examination suggests an underlying bleeding problem, or if the procedure is high-risk (e.g., neurosurgery), then preoperative testing is appropriate. A patient’s report of “easy bruising” without a history of more substantial or serious bleeding is not generally an indication for additional evaluation. If the patient gives a strong family history of a bleeding disorder, the clinician should obtain more information before deciding which additional tests (if any) to order.

Key learning point: The most important way to assess bleeding risk before elective surgery is to obtain a thorough medical history and bleeding history.

C) INCORRECT:

Bleeding time is a test of platelet function with limited clinical utility and is not offered in most clinical laboratories.

D) INCORRECT:

Preoperative coagulation studies are reserved for patients who have a history of bleeding or medical conditions that predispose them to bleeding and for those taking anticoagulants.

E) INCORRECT:

Preoperative coagulation studies are reserved for patients who have a history of bleeding or medical conditions that predispose them to bleeding and for those taking anticoagulants.

questions.text: A 76-year-old man presents to the ED after a ground-level fall and is found to have a displaced femoral neck fracture. He is alert, hemodynamically stable, and pain is controlled. He has atrial fibrillation (CHA2DS2-VASc score 5) and takes apixaban 5 mg twice daily. Orthopedics plans to perform a hemiarthroplasty tomorrow. The patient has his own apixiban tablets with him and wants to take his evening dose as his hematologist said it was very important to never miss a dose. What is the most appropriate response?

choices.text: Take evening apixiban dose, withhold morning dose
Withhold apixaban and start bridging with low-molecular-weight heparin
Withhold apixaban dose
Withold apixaban and reverse residual dose with andexanet alfa
Continue apixaban but lower the dose to 2.5 mg

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Taking apixaban this evening would leave significant residual anticoagulant activity at the time of operation, increasing surgical bleeding risk.

B) INCORRECT:

Bridging is not recommended with DOACs because they have a rapid onset and offset. Bridging would increase bleeding risk without added benefit in this setting.

C) CORRECT:

Correct — This patient requires urgent hip surgery. Continuing apixaban would increase intraoperative bleeding risk. DOACs should be withheld for 48 hours before surgery with a high bleeding risk (if possible). Given his high thromboembolic risk, bridging is not indicated for DOACs because they have a short half-life and their anticoagulant effect resolves quickly on discontinuation. The ED clinician should document the last dose and notify the surgical and anesthesia teams.

D) INCORRECT:

Reversal is only indicated if emergent surgery is required within hours or there is life-threatening bleeding. This patient is stable and surgery is planned for the following day, so reversal is not necessary.

E) INCORRECT:

Lowering the dose does not sufficiently reduce bleeding risk and would leave residual anticoagulant activity during surgery. The drug should be withheld, not reduced.
